content: I edited the Goal a bit to use simple English to make it easily understandable. I also added Shortest mode. I am not sure why we shouldn't do that.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's interesting, but also easy enough to be solved in 5 minutes

I edited the goal to make it reflect what is actualy asked and the statement to make it absolutely clear and the color code for variables/constants. I also added a hint to maybe make people understand it's an optimisation problem.
If it's ok with you like that I will validate.
I have to say it's a very good exercice and it's going to be very frustrating for a lot of people :P

I really like this Clash of Code but I have a problem:
for big number (in test 2, test 3, validator 3 and test 4), the number of divisor is so huge that my program make an error saying it is running for too long.
My program is short and simple. I search on Google more efficient solutions but it seems that I already have the most efficient solution in Python.
I do not approve this contribution because the numbers are too large. Even if you found a solution in Python that work without making an error, I wouldn't agree too because it would be too hard to found and not funny for players.
I propose to set smaller numbers for the test, because moreover it is not useful to put so big number.
If you change that I would be happy to validate your contribution !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Its a quick and fun contribution.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is clear, short to understand and requires simple optimization.
The Logic and the design of the question is beautiful~. However, I didn't really understand the question until I see the output and constraints though.
Please try to address @snoyes comment below.

Good premise.

Some grammatical suggestions:
-What is the number N of divisors of that are divisible by 2?
+How many of the divisors of N are divisible by 2?

-For each testcase, print the required answer in one line.
+For each testcase, print the answer on a separate line.

Looks good. Good job, @ALLAOUA.

I found the description to be clear.

I would like to see a better match between the test cases and their corresponding validator cases (same number of integers, T; similar integer magnitudes, N; similar presence of edge cases, i.e., prime numbers, perfect squares, etc.)

Can you add more descriptive names for the test cases?
It looks like the second line of Constraints in the problem statement should be "1<=N<=10^9", instead of "1<=T<=10^9"

Clever idea!

I haven't seen an optimization puzzle in CoC.

It took me longer than I'd like to admit to figure out the proper way to optimize.

It was a fun puzzle.
Thankkk you
I think one way to fix it, is to get rid of the T lines, and do 1 number per testcase and validator
I think the problem statement was better before the edit, but the color code was a good change

The problem before was that it didn't represent the entire problem. It mentionned only one integer when there is a list of them. Plus he called them 'testcases' which is confusing in my opinion.
How would you have written it?
It can still be changed.
Actually, I'm looking back and forth between the old and new one, and this is better.
I'll wait until tomorrow to see if the author approves of my edit. If he didn't reply I'll validate it like that.

Hey, 
Thank u so much for the edit, it's very clear right now ! 
This was my first exercise, i will do my best next time :)

It's definitely not bad to do, even in Python.
You can't iterate through every number up to N to see if it's a divisor, you have to iterate up to the square root N.
I've taken their reference solution and translated it 1:1 into Python, and it solves all test cases and validators well within the time limit.
It's even faster in python for me
